_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP DATA ELEMENTS

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.      Facility accidental release and emergency response policy.

The management and employees of New Horizon FS, Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Bennett Fire Department, Cedar Co. LEPC Local Emergency Planning Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and environment.

2.      The stationary source and the regulated substance handled.

The primary activity at the facility, which is located at, Bennett is the storage and blending of fertilizer for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  The storage and 
handling system consists of  26,000 gallon storage tank, loading risers, associated plumbing and nurse tanks.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. 

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored would be 398,500 pounds, this includes the amount of anhydrous ammonia that could be stored in nurse tanks.

3.      The worst-case scenario and the alternative release scenario.

The worst-case release would be the release of the total contents of a storage tank released as a gas over 10 minutes.  The maximum quantity released would be  140,000 pounds, which represents the volume of the largest storage tank as limited by design standards.

The distance of the endpoint of .14mg/L for the worst-case scenario is 1.1 miles.

The alternative release scenario based on the most likely potential incident is a release from a break in a transfer hose.  Emergency shutdown procedures, which include the closing of tank valves if possible, otherwise excess flow valves was the only active mitigation considered to limit the amount of product released.

The distance to the en

dpoint of .14mg/L for the alternative scenario is .19 miles.  This release has the possibility of extending beyond the facility boundary.

4.      The accidental release prevention program.

This facility complies with EPA?s Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of ?Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1?, published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U. S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR1910.111.  ?Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia?.  Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident release prevention program.

5.       Historical information on this facility.

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past fine years , that to our knowledge have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, or environmental damage.

6.      The emergency response program.

This facility has:

-A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard,
 29 CFR 1910.38:

-provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).
             
          In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify Bennett Fire Department and Cedar Co. LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency. Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both  the fire department and LEPC

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
